history.content:
Forget about those EE classes. (If you are looking for a class with a low work load for your design class) They all have extremely high work load.

186 is on the lighter side (I honestly don't know why 186 counts as a 'major design experience' class). I didn't think the class is useful at all when I took it but now, working at my internship, I realized that 186 is actually really useful, lets you understand a lot of what people are saying, and, yes, is pretty interesting. (186 has the lowest workload of the bunch.)

---------------------

Hey, don't scare the person away from EE!  It is so much fun!  Wouldn't you like to build something other than a computer program? :)

I can comment on the ones I took:

EE C128 - Typical problem sets and exams; no project but a series of intense labs including magnetic levitation and inverted pendulum.

EE 130 - More physics heavy (it's about how transistors work).  The final project (when I took it) was quite light.

EE 140 - A class about designing op amps and other analog circuits.  Fairly heavy but cool IC design projecct.

EE 143 - You get to fabricate some transistors in the 218 Cory cleanroom.  Depending on the professor you either have problem sets and small lab reports, or no problem sets and two huge lab reports.

EE 106 is about robotics; 192 is about building a robot car.  EECS 149 is about embedded systems; 151 is building a processor out of an FPGA.  I hear 151 has a lot of work.

Forget about those EE classes. (If you are looking for a class with a low work load for your design class) They all have extremely high work load.

186 is on the lighter side (I honestly don't know why 186 counts as a 'major design experience' class). I didn't think the class is useful at all when I took it but now, working at my internship, I realized that 186 is actually really useful, lets you understand a lot of what people are saying, and, yes, is pretty interesting. (186 has the lowest workload of the bunch.)

children.subject: I also really enjoyed CS 162 with Professor Joseph. If you have a good group in that class, it's not that high of a workload.

history.content:
FYI, that is an old list and some of the course numbers have changed. The updated list is:

EE: C106A, C106B, C128, 130, 140, 143, 192

CS: 160, 162, 164, 169, 184, 186 

EECS: 149, 151

EECS major requires to take one design class. Which design class has relatively lower work load? Is that class interesting?

The current EECS design courses are: 
EE C125, C128, 130, 140, 141, 143, C149, 192

CS C149, 150, 160, 162, 164, 169, 184, 186
history.subject: Design Class
